<span><strong style="color:#000">Politics: </strong></span><span>On the 1-year anniversary of the Capitol insurrection, President Biden </span><span><a href="https://apnews.com/article/jan-6-capitol-siege-biden-congress-3dd8fd804c857c23f8e0fe2324c9d8a4?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">denounced</a></span><span> former President Trump and his allies in forceful terms, saying they held a “dagger at the throat of democracy.” Congress hosted a number of remembrance events throughout the day.</span>

<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SCOTUS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/vaccine-mandate-Biden-US-supreme-court?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}">
<font color="#000000">
We’re About to Find Out if They Can Really Do That
</font>
</a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/vaccine-mandate-Biden-US-supreme-court?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" class="">
<img alt="Supreme Court with syringe sticking out of top in front of vaccine cards." style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/3b8e8b6b59434d253cf0fd196503150a3675fe64-1500x1000.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a><span class="source" style="display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px"><small><em><em><em>Francis Scialabba</em></em></em></small></span>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">President Biden has SCOTUS coming in on their off day. The Supreme Court will <a href="https://www.reuters.com/world/us/pandemic-wary-us-supreme-court-weigh-biden-vaccine-mandates-2022-01-05/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">hear</a> arguments during a special hearing today on whether the White House’s two vaccine mandates—that would affect 100 million American workers—can proceed.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The backstory:</strong> In November, President Biden set a January 4 <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/04/biden-sets-deadline-of-jan-4-for-vaccine-mandate-on-large-employers?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">deadline</a> for a) health care workers employed at federally funded facilities to be vaccinated and b) staff at other US companies with more than 100 employees to be vaccinated or get tested weekly. The deadline was extended to February 9 because the announcement spurred a legal mess resembling a Whattaburger dining room after 11pm.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">By the end of November, a coalition of 12 states sued the Biden admin to oppose the mandate. The US Court of Appeals for the 5th Circuit blocked the mandate, then the 6th Circuit blocked <em>that </em>block, and the case was volleyed to the Supreme Court.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0"><strong style="color:#000">The opposition</strong></h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">A mix of 50+ businesses, religious groups, and leaders of Republican-led states will argue that the vaccine mandates are an overreach by federal agencies and that they could exacerbate worker shortages, <em>and </em>force employers to dip into their Friday pizza party fund to pay for all those Covid tests.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px"><li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span><strong style="color:#000">Key info: </strong></span><span>One thing to know about today’s hearing is that SCOTUS won’t be deciding if the mandates are lawful, just whether the Biden team can implement them while litigation in the lower courts continues.</span>
</li></ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">It’s difficult to predict what exactly the court will say, because the federal government has never attempted to impose a vaccine-or-test policy on employers. The court does have a 6–3 conservative majority, which indicates it may not be too fond of broad federal regulations. In August, SCOTUS <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/08/27/supreme-court-throws-bidens-eviction-moratorium?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">rejected</a> an extension of the federal eviction moratorium on grounds that the CDC didn’t have the authority to enforce it.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">On the other hand, the same justices voted in favor of upholding vaccine mandates for local governments, universities, and health care workers in New York and Maine.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead…</strong>some companies aren’t waiting around for the decision. Starbucks told all of its US employees on Monday that they needed to get vaxed or submit to regular testing starting February 9.<em>—MM</em></p>
</div>

<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
MEDIA
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/New-York-Times-acquires-The-Athletic-550-million?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}">
<font color="#000000">
The NYT is Getting Athletic in 2022
</font>
</a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/New-York-Times-acquires-The-Athletic-550-million?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" class="">
<img alt="The New York Times building in Manhattan " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/e8b0b42006e8182e4842c9303c292051c4fe10e8-6048x4024.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a><span class="source" style="display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px"><small><em>Getty Images/Johannes Eisele</em></small></span>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The New York Times is scooping up subs like it’s first in line on free lunch day. The media company has agreed to acquire subscription-based sports site The Athletic <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-01-06/n-y-times-is-said-to-buy-the-athletic-in-a-550-million-deal?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">for $550 million</a> in a deal that will help the Times reach its goal of being able to claim 10 million paid digital subscribers by 2025.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Founded in 2016 and boasting around 1.2 million subscribers, The Athletic has been shopping for a buyer for months after reportedly burning through more than $95 million between 2019 and 2020. The cash drain mainly had to do with the hiring of 600 full-time employees across North America, the UK, and Australia—all part of the effort to build a global audience of sports geeks.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The Athletic has raised around $140 million to date and was valued at $500 million in early 2020.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">How they got here: </strong>Local newspaper layoffs were a key part of the success of The Athletic, as the site scooped up popular sports writers in smaller markets. In 2017, co-founder Alex Mather told the NYT, “We will wait every local paper out and let them continuously bleed. …We will suck them dry of their best talent at every moment.”—<em>MK</em></p>
</div>

INTERNATIONAL
</h3>

<a target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/01/06/undefined?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}">
<font color="#000000">
Why the World Is Watching Kazakhstan
</font>
</a>
</h1>
</td>

<a style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/01/06/undefined?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" class="">
<img alt="A burned-out automobile in Almaty, Kazakhstan" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/0ba885dc37c50361f21d202ee8783e584c90c10e-7952x5304.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a><span class="source" style="display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px"><small><em>ALEXANDER BOGDANOV/AFP via Getty Images</em></small></span>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The Central Asian country of Kazakhstan is probably popping up on your news feed a lot more than it used to. Here’s what’s going on.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Violent protests <a href="https://www.axios.com/kazakhstan-unrest-russia-sends-forces-2081f833-f242-4dae-9746-f4af7aebedd8.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">erupted</a> this week after the government lifted price caps on liquified petroleum gas, which many Kazakhs use to fuel their cars. Dozens of demonstrators and state security forces have been killed in the worst street violence in decades. Yesterday, Russia sent paratroopers into the former Soviet state after the Kazakh government asked for help in quelling the protests.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Global ramifications</strong></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Kazakhstan is a <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2022/01/06/massive-protests-in-kazakhstan-spur-russian-involvement.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">huge country</a>, about 4x the size of Texas. But the country’s vast natural resources, including gas, oil, coal, and minerals, make it an important area for energy giants like ExxonMobil, Shell, and Chevron.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px"><li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Kazakhstan is also the world’s top supplier of the radioactive metal, producing 40% of the global supply. Uranium prices jumped nearly 8% from Tuesday to Wednesday as a result of the turmoil.</span></li></ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">And of course there’s a <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jan/06/kazakhstan-bitcoin-internet-shutdown?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">crypto angle</a>: Kazakhstan is the second-largest country for bitcoin mining after the US, but because of an internet shutdown this week, a big chunk of the global bitcoin network’s computing power has been knocked offline.—<em>NF</em></p>
</div>

<a target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2022/01/06/key-performance-indicators-january-7?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}">

Key Performance Indicators
</font>
</a>
</h1>
</td>

</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Stat: </strong>With Omicron denting air travel demand, Lufthansa said it would have to fly an <a href="https://apnews.com/article/coronavirus-pandemic-business-health-greta-thunberg-europe-46f83ff11edb3f866a581fcec515164f?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">extra 18,000 “unnecessary” flights</a> (aka flights that are nearly empty) this winter in order to hold onto airport slots under EU regulations. Both airlines and environmentalists are urging the EU to change its airport slot rules so these polluting and financially draining ghost flights don’t have to take place.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Quote: </strong>“I think if he wanted, he would be playing here in Australia without a problem.”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Tennis star Rafael Nadal <a href="https://www.bbc.com/sport/tennis/59892388?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">remarked</a> on his rival Novak Djokovic’s predicament with a “sorry not sorry” attitude. Djokovic was denied entry to the country under its vaccination policy, and is currently being held in a government detention hotel until at least Monday, when a court will hear an appeal. The tournament begins one week later.<br><br><strong style="color:#000">Read: </strong>Where’s today’s Beethoven? (<a href="https://www.cold-takes.com/wheres-todays-beethoven/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Cold Takes</a>)</p>
</div>

on their off day. The Supreme Court will \u003ca href=\"https://www.reuters.com/world/us/pandemic-wary-us-supreme-court-weigh-biden-vaccine-mandates-2022-01-05/?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ehear\u003c/a\u003e arguments during a special hearing today on whether the White House’s two vaccine mandates—that would affect 100 million American workers—can proceed.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe backstory:\u003c/strong\u003e In November, President Biden set a January 4 \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/04/biden-sets-deadline-of-jan-4-for-vaccine-mandate-on-large-employers?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\u0026mid={{md5(profile.email)}}\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edeadline\u003c/a\u003e for a) health care workers employed at federally funded facilities to be vaccinated and b) staff at other US companies with more than 100 employees to be vaccinated or get tested weekly. The deadline was extended to February 9 because the announcement spurred a legal mess resembling a Whattaburger dining room after 11pm.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBy the end of November, a coalition of 12 states sued the Biden admin to oppose the mandate. The US Court of Appeals for the 5th Circuit blocked the mandate, then the 6th Circuit blocked \u003cem\u003ethat \u003c/em\u003eblock, and the case was volleyed to the Supreme Court.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe opposition\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eA mix of 50+ businesses, religious groups, and leaders of Republican-led states will argue that the vaccine mandates are an overreach by federal agencies and that they could exacerbate worker shortages, \u003cem\u003eand \u003c/em\u003eforce employers to dip into their Friday pizza party fund to pay for all those Covid tests.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eKey info: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eOne thing to know about today’s hearing is that SCOTUS won’t be deciding if the mandates are lawful, just whether the Biden team can implement them while litigation in the lower courts continues.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIt’s difficult to predict what exactly the court will say, because the federal government has never attempted to impose a vaccine-or-test policy on employers. The court does have a 6–3 conservative majority, which indicates it may not be too fond of broad federal regulations. In August, SCOTUS \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/08/27/supreme-court-throws-bidens-eviction-moratorium?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\u0026mid={{md5(profile.email)}}\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003erejected\u003c/a\u003e an extension of the federal eviction moratorium on grounds that the CDC didn’t have the authority to enforce it.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eOn the other hand, the same justices voted in favor of upholding vaccine mandates for local governments, universities, and health care workers in New York and Maine.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead…\u003c/strong\u003esome companies aren’t waiting around for the decision. Starbucks told all of its US employees on Monday that they needed to get vaxed or submit to regular testing starting February 9.\u003cem\u003e—MM\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe New York Times is scooping up subs like it’s first in line on free lunch day. The media company has agreed to acquire subscription-based sports site The Athletic \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-01-06/n-y-times-is-said-to-buy-the-athletic-in-a-550-million-deal?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003efor $550 million\u003c/a\u003e in a deal that will help the Times reach its goal of being able to claim 10 million paid digital subscribers by 2025.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eFounded in 2016 and boasting around 1.2 million subscribers, The Athletic has been shopping for a buyer for months after reportedly burning through more than $95 million between 2019 and 2020. The cash drain mainly had to do with the hiring of 600 full-time employees across North America, the UK, and Australia—all part of the effort to build a global audience of sports geeks.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe Athletic has raised around $140 million to date and was valued at $500 million in early 2020.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eHow they got here: \u003c/strong\u003eLocal newspaper layoffs were a key part of the success of The Athletic, as the site scooped up popular sports writers in smaller markets. In 2017, co-founder Alex Mather told the NYT, “We will wait every local paper out and let them continuously bleed. …We will suck them dry of their best talent at every moment.”—\u003cem\u003eMK\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe Central Asian country of Kazakhstan is probably popping up on your news feed a lot more than it used to. Here’s what’s going on.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eViolent protests \u003ca href=\"https://www.axios.com/kazakhstan-unrest-russia-sends-forces-2081f833-f242-4dae-9746-f4af7aebedd8.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eerupted\u003c/a\u003e this week after the government lifted price caps on liquified petroleum gas, which many Kazakhs use to fuel their cars. Dozens of demonstrators and state security forces have been killed in the worst street violence in decades. Yesterday, Russia sent paratroopers into the former Soviet state after the Kazakh government asked for help in quelling the protests.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eGlobal ramifications\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eKazakhstan is a \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2022/01/06/massive-protests-in-kazakhstan-spur-russian-involvement.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ehuge country\u003c/a\u003e, about 4x the size of Texas. But the country’s vast natural resources, including gas, oil, coal, and minerals, make it an important area for energy giants like ExxonMobil, Shell, and Chevron.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eKazakhstan is also the world’s top supplier of the radioactive metal, producing 40% of the global supply. Uranium prices jumped nearly 8% from Tuesday to Wednesday as a result of the turmoil.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAnd of course there’s a \u003ca href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/world/2022/jan/06/kazakhstan-bitcoin-internet-shutdown?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecrypto angle\u003c/a\u003e: Kazakhstan is the second-largest country for bitcoin mining after the US, but because of an
